one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. From the past week's study, what made the most significant impact to you in the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read 1 Kings 11:1-8.
Solomon loved forbidden women and worshipped false gods.

questions.questionText: 3. What commands did Solomon disobey? (See Exodus 34:11-17; Deuteronomy 17:16-17 or any other Scripture reference.)
4. Why does God set boundaries around marriage? How are God's boundaries for marriage for the good of His children, then and now?
5. How do you proceed when God's commands come into conflict with your decisions and desires?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read 1 Kings 11:9-13.
God promised to divide the kingdom because of Solomon's disobedience.

questions.questionText: 6. Why was God angry with Solomon? Why does God command our undivided worship? (Use Psalm 16:11; Ecclesiastes 2:1-10; Isaiah 45:5-6; 46:3-10; Acts 17:25 or any Scripture reference.)
7. Solomon attempted to worship God and idols. What are some present-day examples of idolatry? What in your life might be an idol?
8. What consequences did God promise would come to Solomon and his kingdom? What do you learn about God's timing, justice and mercy?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read 1 Kings 11:14-26.
God raised up adversaries against Solomon.

questions.questionText: 9. Describe the adversaries God "raised up" against Solomon. How did God demonstrate faithfulness to His promises? (See 1 Kings 6:12; 9:3-9)
10. What are the opposing forces God's people face today? (For help, see John 15:18-21; Ephesians 6:12; 1 Peter 5:8; James 1:13-14; 1 John 2:16.)
11. What is your first response when hardship and adversaries arise? How has God used opposition and hardship to turn your heart and attention back to Him?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read 1 Kings 11:26-43; Ecclesiastes 9:12; 12:1-14.
Jeroboam learned God's intent to give him 10 tribes.

questions.questionText: 12. What did the Lord promise Jeroboam? What were the conditions?
13. What can you infer about Solomon's last months of life? Why did he summarize life as he did? (See Ecclesiastes 9:12; 12:1-14.)
14. As you reflect back over Solomon's life, what lessons do you want to remember? How will they shape the way you live?
15. What attribute of God resonated most from your study of this week's passage? How do you see that attribute displayed in the world today?
16. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: 1 Kings 11.
